question: It is only illegal to sell, not buy, cannabis.

answer.text: Selling or buying drugs such as heroin, cocaine, ecstasy and cannabis is illegal in the UK.

question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: In Scotland, serious offences are tried in a Sheriff Court.
options.B: In Scotland, serious offences are tried in a Crown Court.

answer.text: In Scotland, serious cases are heard in a Sheriff Court with either a sheriff or a sheriff with a jury.

question: What is the minimum age to legally buy tobacco products?

answer.text: It is illegal to sell tobacco products (for example, cigarettes, cigars and roll-up tobacco) to anyone under the age of 18.

question: What is the name of the court that deals with minor criminal cases in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?

answer.text: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court.

question: Which TWO of the following are true of Youth Courts?

options.A: The media are allowed in to take photographs of the accused
options.B: Three magistrates or a District Judge hears the case
options.C: The family or carer of the accused is expected to be in court
options.D: The media are expected to publish the name and details of the accused

answer.text: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, if an accused person is aged 10 to 17, the case is normally heard in a Youth Court in front of up to three specially trained magistrates or a District Judge. The parents or carers of the young person are expected to attend the hearing.

question: In England and Wales, which TWO of the following are allowed to be present in a Youth Court hearing?

options.A: The parents or carers of the young person

answer.text: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, Youth Court cases are heard in front of up to three specially trained magistrates or a District Judge. The parents or carers of the young person are expected to attend the hearing. Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts.

question: How many members does a jury have in England?

answer.text: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has 15 members.

question: You can only complain about the police to the Chief Constable of the police force involved.

answer.text: Anyone can make a complaint about the police by going to a police station or writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved. Complaints can also be made to the relevant independent body in England, Wales, Scotland or Northern Ireland.

question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: An example of a civil law case is when you have made a legal complaint about a faulty item you have purchased.

answer.text: Civil law relates to disputes between individuals or groups. This covers things such as housing law, consumer rights, employment law and debt.

question: Which one of the following is a criminal offence?

options.A: Smoking in an enclosed public place
options.D: A dispute over rent between a tenant and landlord

answer.text: Laws can be divided into criminal law and civil law: - Criminal law relates to crimes, which are usually investigated by the police or another authority such as a council, and which are punished by the courts. - Civil law is used to settle disputes between individuals or groups.

question: What is the limit for the small claims procedure in Scotland and Northern Ireland?

answer.text: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales and £3,000 in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

question: What is the limit for the small claims procedure in England and Wales?

answer.text: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales and £3,000 in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

question: Who can make a complaint about the police?

answer.text: If something goes wrong, the police complaints system tries to put it right. Anyone can make a complaint about the police by going to a police station or writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved. Complaints can also be made to an independent body in England and Wales. In Scotland, if you are unhappy with the way your complaint has been handled, you can contact the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner. In Northern Ireland, you should contact the Police Ombudsman's Office.

question: Causing trouble whilst drinking in public can result in which TWO of the following?

answer.text: Some places have alcohol-free zones where you cannot drink in public. The police can also confiscate alcohol or move young people on from public places. You can be fined or arrested.

question: Where are minor criminal cases tried in a Justice of the Peace Court?

question: In which part of the UK does a legally qualified District Judge or Deputy District Judge hear cases in the Magistrates' Court?
